Qualitative studies
Discover existence of problems, relatively small number of participants
"What people dislike about the app?", "How can a process be improved?"Quantitative studies
Results are numbers, large volume of data needed
"How often do users need undo?", "How long does it take to select an menu item?"

Performed by an expert, checks heuristics rules, e.g. Nielsen's Heuristics:
Visibility of system status
Match between system and the real world
User control and freedom
Consistency and standards
Error prevention
Recognition rather than recall
Flexibility and efficiency of use
Aesthetic and minimalist design
Help users recognize, diagnose, and recover from errors
Help and documentation
Performed by an expert, "What the user would do"
Users respond using a form (e.g. mark statements from strongly agree to strongly disagree). Easy to administer and easy to process, but limited insights. Should be as short as possible.

Key part is observing real users using the product to discover errors and areas of improvement
Usability engineering = usability testing in an usability lab, controlled environment
Screener = quick questionnaire to determine we have a person in the targetted demographic (gender, hobbies, age, occupation, etc.)
